In another, you are taping adhesive foam to cover holes in the bracket. In both cases, there is not enough foam ribbon or adhesive foam, and my window is only 32" wide. Easy enough, just bought more at hardware store, but I was surprised that even after applying the four different foam materials as instructed, there was still a lot of space left to fill, especially considering how well everything else was designed (including the app). Def an amazing purchase.

CommentsTitle: Not recommended for humid climate - lack of drainage hole causes stagnant and odorous water buildup
CommentsContent: Bought this unit 3 months ago based on good general reviews and innovative designs. Installation was pretty easy and I followed directions to make sure it slanted backwards. Unit ran well and was good at meeting my cooling needs; everything seemed great at first.About 2 months in, started noticing a foul smell whenever the fans first start running from idle. Cleaned out the filter but the issue persisted. Started googling about this and discovered that many people had complaints with mold growth in this unit due to difficulty in taking the unit apart for cleaning, and also lack of drainage hole in the outside portion.I finally took the unit down and opened it up outside after the smell became unbearable and started to negatively affect my health. I discovered that about a third of the bottom of the outside unit is constantly submerged in about an inch and half of gross brownish gunky water filled dead bugs and god knows what. This water just sits there stagnant in the back of the ac, not high enough to spill out of the overflow, and a sniff confirmed that this was indeed the source of the same smell that I was getting indoors.After researching extensively into this topic, I found that Midea purposely doesn't have drainage holes in this unit so the fan can scope up the residual water buildup and splash it around as a cooling mechanism to save energy. There are however problems I found with this explanation; First of all, the circular scoop that the fan uses to pick up the water doesn't sit flush against the bottom of the case; Its actually about an inch up. This means that there needs to be at least an inch of water inside the case for it to even start using this feature. Unless this water is freshly condensed and then evaporates out routinely, you are going to have a stagnant water buildup inside this case, especially if you live anywhere humid like I do. What ends up happening is that you get a pool of gunky water filled with gross mold and whatnots, that the fan then picks up and proceeds to splash on all the fins in the machine, which eventually translates to unpleasant odor being blown into your room whenever it starts up.I rather not be breathing nasty, disease causing air compared to Midea hitting an energy saver milestone. At least give us the option of drain holes with plugs or something so we can choose between efficiency vs cleanliness . Unless you live somewhere really dry, or doesn't need to use this thing often, I cannot recommend a purchase of this unit. Giving it two stars because it actually works well with cooling (so far), but this is a major issue.Also. the fans on the indoor portion of the ac cannot be reached to be cleaned unless you take the entire front portion apart, unhooking wires, cables and all. Very unfriendly design for sustainable general maintenance.

CommentsContent: I bought the 8,000 BTU Midea window unit for our master bedroom and now I can set the thermostats for both floors up to about 80° during the night and my master bedroom can be set on 67° for the night. We are empty nesters so this works for us. If your other bedrooms are occupied you probably have to run your central unit or put one of these small units in each bedroom. I don't see the reason to cool my entire 3100 sq ft two story home during the night just to make it comfortabel in the 200 sq ft master bedroom. My electric bill dropped to about 1/3 of what it was and we sleep at a much cooler temperature. The unit is also very quiet on lower speeds. It has a variable speed motor so after the room cools down the unit will run at such a low speed you cannot even hear it. The vent only stays open when the AC is running and sometimes I'll walk by and the vent is open and I'm thinking "is that thing running". And I'll put my hand in front of it and I can feel cold air coming out. Although when  you first turn it on and it's running on high speed you can hear it but its more of a louder humm.The only Con is that about once a year you have to vacuum the blades of the squirrel cage fan that blows the cold air or air flow slow down to about nothing. And Midea put some sort of wire quard in front of the squirrel cage fan blade that prevents easy cleaning. Here's what I did; take a pair of pliers and just pull the wire quard out of the unit. To do this you have to bend the air flow cover up in the center and pop it off the two pegs that hold it in to be able to get at the fan. Then pull the grey plastic air diverter blades up out of the holes and set them aside. Then with a pair of pliers or wire cutters pull that damn wire guard out so you get a vacuum in there and vacuum the fan blades. You can probably expect to do this once a year. Once you get the guard out of the way and toss it in the trash the rest of the job is really easy to do once or twice a year.I like the wi-fi app making it easy to set the temp way down. We can be across town and before we are heading home for the evening I'll open my app and turn the unit on. By the time we get up to the bedroom it's 67° while the outside temp is a blazing 100° and the rest of the house is set to 80°. This little unit has paid for itself in the first few months.

CommentsTitle: Good little a/c unit for the garage
CommentsContent: I bought this for my garage. I live in Alabama. It is March 7, 2023 and was 86 degrees today. This air conditioner was delivered today, so you know I had to install it! Packaging was easy to remove. Now, I must have the world's smallest window in my garage. It's an old, metal frame window. When I read the description, it seemed like it would fit perfectly after measuring my window. The unit itself fit no problem. The issue was the side panels. It was just like an inch too big horizontally to fit my window. However, I remedied this issue by cutting an inch off of the left and right panel frames. Doing this allowed it to fit perfectly. The height was fine. The screws it comes with are kind of junk, but they work for what you need. Also, the mounting brackets didnt work for me, but again, I have some crazy windowns, apparently. So I made my modifications, installed it, and turned it on. Initially, it made a lot of noise kicking on the first time. Now it's quite quiet. It's blowing out some seriously cold air. I am in the process of insulating my garage (already did the garage doors, working on throwing up the panels on the rafters). I think this is going make working on my cars during the summer exponentially better. I don't know how it will do in the full blown summer yet, but I have high hopes. It will at least be tolerable. I'll update in a few months if anything goes wrong with it. Side note: if you want to insulate your garage with insulation panels, go to Lowes over home depot. I got Poly Pro 3/4" thick 4' x 8' panels for approx. $15 a piece. Just use a sharp utility knife to cut it and gorilla glue hot glue sticks to mount it to your garage door panels (you'll need to put blocks of the insulation panels on the garage doors before you install your cut panels or else the height won't be right. You'll know what I'm talking about if you go to do it.) Thank me later.

CommentsTitle: Not "like new" as stated, more like "like fell out window"
CommentsContent: I took a chance on the "like new" return.  Since other reviews said it had a design fault of not having a drain hole for condensation, I figured I could solve it with a drill if needed.  The description of the one that I selected said the box had cosmetic damage, but that the unit was like new.  Well, the owners manual and installation guide was still wrapped in plastic, unopened.  That was the only part "like new"1. All the mounting hardware was missing.2. The fresh air vent was broke off and wedged in the fan blades.3. The front looked like it had been pried off, and then the prior owners seem to have tried to reattach it with silicone glue.4. The electrical plug was crushed, with the ground plug broke off.5. The plastic on the inside was covered with paint and silicone.6. The metal cabinet was badly crushed on one side, it looked like it might have fallen out of a window7. Despite the prior owners troubles, they must have got it working for a while, as the filter had a good layer of dog hair (or maybe cat or llama?) covering it. It was also obvious it had been run a while as their was plenty of residue from dried up water in the back, that hadn't drained out.Initially, I was just going to see if I could return it.  But I repair stuff, so I figured I might as well see what it would take to get it running.  I was able to take apart the cabinet, (after scraping illicit silicon of the screw heads) as per the instructions and get the fresh air vent and lever out of the fan blades and back in place. Also, since I had followed the instructions for taking off the front, I was able to get it back together correctly, unlike the prior owners.  The plug is missing the ground plug, clean broke off, but I was able to bend the other prongs into shape enough to plug it in for a brief test.  (I will have to cut the end off and add a new 3 prong repair before actually using it--it would be dangerous to use a metal appliance without a ground!  Unfortunately, this will mean cutting out the GFCI protection at the end of the cord. But I will be plugging it into a GFCI outlet, so that will provide the needed protection.)  After letting it run a while, it did start blowing cold air.  Living in the Pacific Northwest, I only plan to use it a few weeks during the summer. So I guess I will keep it.  But I won't be able to review any other qualities, or lack thereof, until then.

CommentsContent: During a recent failure of our building's central AC, our small server room hit 106 degrees F.  The surrounding rooms were 85 F with no heat on.  Uncomfortable for us and bad for the servers!We put this in there, ducted it to the room's one small window, set it to 80 degrees, and turned it on.An hour later, it was down to 95 F in the server room.  When we returned the next morning, it was 80 degrees in there, and the surrounding rooms were back to 72 F.Disaster averted!Compared to many others, the real advantage of this unit is that the duct is split between intake and outflow.  Meaning it has two loops internally.  One from and to the room and the second from and to the outside.  It exchanges the heat from the room loop to the outside loop and then sends the air from each back where it came from.This means it cools highly efficiently without creating negative pressure in the room by exhausting hot air outside without replacing it.This doesn't cool as much as central AC but costs less to operate.  For those times of year (spring and fall) when we only need AC because of the server room, this may save us money!If this thing can cool 2.5kW of servers and switches, it ought to do a pretty good job in any household application.The one thing I really can't weigh in on is the noise level; that room already has a "hearing protection required to enter" sign on the door.If I could change one thing, I would make the included duct longer.  But given our niche use, that's probably not an issue for most people.

CommentsTitle: Would be 5 star except it leaks in outside air defeating the purpose of a dual hose system
CommentsContent: I'd love to be able to recommend this unit. It is generally quiet (can get temporarily loud at random times which is bad in a bedroom overnight), has good features, a great remote, and sips power (relatively) but the unit is poorly sealed and as a result outside air easily enters your home via the intake hose when the unit is off, and when it is on it sucks air from your home to blow out the exhaust causing negative pressure and external air to be sucked in from other ingress points around the home.I have two of these units purchased 4 months apart. When I owned the first one it was installed in such a location that the negative pressure was not noticeable but when I brought a second unit and placed it in my bedroom I noticed it would pull the door open if not properly latched when the AC was turned on. Glad of the cool air and happy with the other features I put it to the back of my mind until the wildfire season came and the stink billowed out both units horribly. Placing my nose near the rear body vent it became clear that the smell was entering via the intake hose when the unit was off. I also noticed that on cooler nights a cold draft would drift from the same vents.I removed the dual hose from the unit to investigate and noticed large dust deposits around the poorly sealing areas around where the hose mates to the AC body. Flashing a flashlight around I also realized that the holes in the back of the unit for the plug to sit in go directly into the external air chamber allowing another place for air to mix. Similarly more holes further down the back of the unit do the same. Shine a flashlight around the underside and you will see light shine up unimpeded into the external air chamber. The hole in the bottom where the power cable exits is so large I can fit a whole finger in it (as well as the power cable) and that too goes straight into the external air chamber.In short, while I have no doubt this unit creates much less negative pressure issues than a single hose unit if you are expecting to keep outside air out (including pollution and smells) this unit will fail you miserably. It defeats one of the main selling points. It makes it useless as a heater in the winter as so much cold air will seep into the house defeating another major selling point. I'm sad I paid so much for a system that is so poorly designed and built. Remember, I have two of these unit and both are the same. They were purchased 4 months apart so this is not a one off or a problem with a specific lot.  It has a great feature set but this takes all that away. Wish I'd never brought them.

CommentsTitle: Thoughts on the Midea Duo 14,000 BTU after two months of ownership
CommentsContent:
I waited a couple of months to see how the experience held up before submitting a review. Before purchase I had wondered about the drainage situation, performance, and overall noise level. I can address these points fully now.

The Midea Duo is a wonderful machine -- in a small bedroom (roughly 11x11) setting this to the lowest setting (60 degrees Fahrenheit) will actually take a space this small down into the mid / upper 50s. This is while the machine copes easily with southeastern heat and humidity outside.

I watched a Youtube reviewer test the noise level, and yes, that very low decibel rating is accurate with one caveat. The minimum noise level advertised only happens on low fan when the unit is in air circulation mode, no AC active -- the compressor running will easily exceed that level even on the lowest settings.

Don't get me wrong -- I work at a desk approximately four feet away from the unit and I have absolutely no issues doing my job. There is a quirk of the unit where when the AC first activates, it briefly will spin everything up to maximum even with the settings configured to low / medium. This will last about thirty seconds before the inverter tech kicks in and the compressor drops into background noise. This is my only pet peeve overall.

I am unsure as to why there isn't a "quiet mode" setting where it will run the compressor at a low setting more often for longer periods to maintain temperature versus needing to run full power for a bit. I would absolutely love this as a feature. Sending the compressor all the way to maximum and maximum fans briefly before stepping back and operating quietly is annoying, but I will note that I do not consider this loud enough to interrupt my day. Sitting further away will mitigate the issue completely.

The noise is never enough to wake me from sleep and isn't "terrible". On normal low AC settings outside of the initial "start up" where it runs full tilt, I would say it is about as loud as box fan set to medium-low. The full start up level of noise for the compressor is approximately as loud as a window AC running on full. You will definitely notice the different stages as it cycles up and down.

This thing will freeze you out of a room and quickly drop the temperature. I have never seen anything like it. Even dealing with Florida heat and humidity it was able to take a heat soaked room that was in the upper 80s down to the low 70s in a span of two hours.

I had some concerns about needing to drain this vs a comparable Whynter unit with their exhaust technology. Those concerns were unfounded -- even with Florida humidity I have never needed to drain the unit. I have checked multiple times but I have never had more than a few drops of water in the tank. The AC exhausts the water vapor efficiently out through the window and does not seem to accumulate much at all.

I have not needed to use the dehumidifying option, so that option may require more draining. For normal AC use you will probably not need to drain it often at all. If you live in a drier climate than Florida, you will probably never need to give draining it a second thought at all.

Installation was not difficult for one person and all needed adapters / panels are provided. Midea supplies extra panels and adapters in case you need extensions. I do recommend reviewing the instructions and using the dampening foam panels to keep outside noise and heat away. You can install it without the instructions (it's that simple) but your life will be much easier if you read the manual. :) Make sure to install the hose flow separator at the end of the vent or your performance will not be as great.

Once the foam is installed and the window secured with the included foam liners, outside noise is no worse than what it was before with the window closed. Midea has done very well in thinking of customer comfort.

Durability -- it cools just as well as it did on day one. It has, however, developed a very annoying rattle/vibration when the compressor spins up and goes to full power. This sounds like something vibrating loose in the unit and this happened a few weeks into ownership.

If I press my hand to the side of the unit this is goes away, so perhaps some piece of sound insulation has let go internally? I do not know if it is a defect since it is cooling perfectly, but I had to take away from the noise level stars because this is annoying and something I notice daily. Before it started doing this vibration-rattle the unit was much quieter.

Purely fan mode is wonderfully quiet, so I know this has to be coming from the compressor somehow.

Make sure to clean and check the filters, as the mesh is very fine and this unit needs the airflow to operate at best performance. I have not needed to use the heat function since we're still in the upper 80s and 90s, but will update as I use it.

The remote control is good for when you don't want to get out of bed to change settings, but I find the app to be easier to use. The remote can do most of the things the buttons on the unit will do minus a few options that require the unit buttons to be held down. The app will let you fine tune most settings on the unit and select fan speeds beyond low, medium, or high. I would like to see full control from the app with all settings that can be adjusted on the unit itself.

Our power bill did not increase by much using the AC. Part of this is probably helped by the Midea taking some of the strain off of the old (and inefficient) wall units here. I normally leave it set to low fan circulation and around 72 degrees on the AC. It uses much less power than a comparable window unit and I would absolutely not have anything other than an inverter driven AC at this point. The technology is that good.

Would I buy another Midea again? Absolutely. There are improvements they can make to the overall build quality (addressing the various vibrations / rattles that have appeared) and settings (a quiet AC mode would be greatly appreciated), but overall this is very comparable with the best that Whynter has to offer and the thoughtfulness of the app is wonderful.

It is not cheap, but the price gives you a tremendous performance and feature combination. I have no doubt that this would cool a large living room or combined space with ease. Thank you to Midea for saving me from Florida Summer!

Edit and followup: I attached two decibel measurements. The average for medium fan is 54 and the average for the unit running in AC mode is 61 with spikes up to 68.

I finally ran the heat and it works great, though it will collect a lot of humidity as condensation in the trays. The unit is very easy to drain, but you can also switch to dry mode to have the unit evaporate and exhaust the water.

Once everything is in place and settled, this unit has worked very well for cooling my ~550 sq. ft. space.
